segments.text: Okay, you said that you were working the steam pumps over at the Big Lump?
Big Lump, yeah.
And that was... And at the recluta, I come and work for the witch mine, they used to call it.
Well, I worked there a little while.
Mr. Sam Yokel was the boss, and he told me, Thomas, I heard that you could work on the steam pumps, pumps and water coolers.
And I said, yeah.
So he gave me the job in the recluta.
Working the steam pumps.
So you weren't working underground?
Yeah.
The steam pumps were down in the ground, too.
The steam pumps were down in the ground?
Yeah.
And I worked on the harvesting engine, harvesting the coal out of the coal mine.
I see.
Like Agostino Garcia.
I see.
And how did you get paid?
Well, I don't remember.
I think it was a general price, about $2.
Okay.
Yeah.
And how many hours a day did you work?
Worked from 6 until I got to get up in the morning, fire up the boiler.
raise the steam to let the hand of the workmen go down to the coal.
Worked about nine hours sometimes, 10 hours.
Did you prefer running the steam engine to coal mining?
Yeah.
You made more money that way, didn't you?
Yeah, and it was not hard as work, because it was hard on my eyes.
When I fired the boiler, see, that was hot.
You think that's why your eyes are kind of bad?
I think so.
But they told me in town, they told me that it was mines with about 200,000 diabetes.
At all the mines, let's see, you worked at the Bogle mine, the Texas Coal Company mine, the Big Lump mine, the Witcher mine.
Yeah.
I worked at the Worley mine.
At the Worley mine.
And with all that experience, did you ever see any accidents?
No.
At all those mines, did they take the mules down in the morning and bring them up?
They'd come down in the morning, bring them out, feed them, give them some hay and corn.
Now, local folk company, they used to give them some corn down in the corn.
They'd tear some corn down in the hay and would feed them good.
Down inside the mine?
Inside the mine.
Would they take them out of the mine every night?
They'd take them out every evening.
What kind of mules were they?
Were they big mules?
Well, ordinary mules.
Ordinary mules, okay.
Some big and some little.
Have you ever owned any land yourself?
Yeah.
When did you own it and how did you get it?
Well, I tell you, I bought it in the camp.
I bought 30 acres of land with a two-story building.
Where did you save the money to buy the land?
I bought it in the bank.
It was on credit.
On credit?
Paid so much to pay.
I see.
And you used the money from working at the mine to pay off?
No, there was no coal mine then.
Yeah, but I landed in 1943, I think it was.
I see.
And after my wife died, I sold the land and moved the house right here in town.
So after that, I sold a house, and that's me without a house.
Did you ever attend, did you attend church every week?
Did most of the people attend church out there?
Well, I did for my, I mean, right there, yeah.
Every Sunday.
They'd walk in?
Yeah.
Yeah, people live right here.
Some of them got a car, well, they go to church on that car.
Did the Mexican people have their own church?
No.
They went to...
Most of the people, the Spanish people, they're Catholics.
And they got a Catholic church here.
I see.
Were you glad when the mines shut down?
Well, I was not too glad.
You see, that's the only kind of work that I had done in my life, work at the coal mines.
What did you do when the mines shut down?
Well, just like I told you a while ago, I went to pick cotton.
When it was ready to be picked, I picked cotton, and then I'd go out and cut wood, grub.
What did the other Spanish people do?
What did the other Spanish people do when the mines shut down?
Well, they did the same thing.
Some of them went to farms.
There don't seem to be that many Spanish people left around Rockdale.
No.
What happened to the United States?
Well, they all moved away.
You know where they moved and why?
Yeah, some of them moved from Malakoff.
Some of them moved from Rockdale to Malakoff.
And from Malakoff, some of the coal mines played out.
And some of them went to Lorain, Ohio.
Some of them in Indiana.
Several places.
Some of them, they transport them back to Mexico.
Those that don't want to go to Mexico, the company would transport the people.
The company would transfer them back?
Yeah.
I see.
Transported up to, like, Malakoff, you know, people working there.
There was no more coal mines.
There was a lot of Spanish people there.
They sent them back, some of them, to Mexico.
Some of them, they went out of the state of Texas to work.
Uh, do you remember any times when new miners would come up from Mexico?
No.
I mean, uh, how did, uh, how did the Spanish people get here to work the mines?
Well, some of them there was, uh, farmers, and they went to work in that coal mine, because they could make a little more money every day.
I see.
I was under the impression that the, uh,
coal companies went down to Mexico and brought Spanish people up here?
No, some people, you know, some of the Spanish people, they had a family here and had some of them in Mexico.
Well, they go to the head man of the coal mine and ask him to let them have some money so they could bring in the people from Mexico.
And that's the way it is.
But there was a lot of Mexican people here that they come from Mexico.
Some of them
from the other coal mines in the United States.
When did your dad come here from Mexico?
He was from Mexico, yeah.
What part of Mexico?
From Guanajuato.
Guanajuato.
Guanajuato.
Do you remember when he came to Texas?
1889, I think.
I see.
You were born 1890.
Can you think of any humorous stories that happened at the mine?
Anything that makes you laugh?
You were telling me about that Model T that fell in the shaft one day.
Oh yeah, that was a fella, you know, they was cutting wood for Mr. Noye.
And they got up one Monday morning, I think they must have been drinking or something.
And they stayed up, I think, Saturday night, all night, or Sunday night.
And they got up and set up a bottle of tea.
You know, they went down in that gully, you know, within that branch of it.
They went down and come up, and they lost the road somehow.
Was it their bottle of tea?
Yeah.
Well, can you think of anything else you'd like to?
That's all I can think of.
Did the Spanish people seem to be happy here at Tomas?
Oh, yeah.
Was there ever any trouble of any sort?
Oh, well, sometimes a little fight.
Fish fight, I don't know.
Okay, well, I sure do thank you, Tomas.
I appreciate
your patience more than anything else.
Well, that's okay.
Like I told you a while ago, there's nothing I can do to help you go around there and show them old coal holes.
